8.8.17  7:44 am   I would like to be an opera singer, I love it and my teachers told me I had potential but it's not the music style I enjoy listening to the most (although it's beautiful, but it's just not what I prefer) and I like singing jazz and soul and stuff too. But what bothers me most is that most young people or even older ones are not into opera at all, I think mostly because cultural marketing isn't done very well and doesn't manage to draw new audiences. How many times have I heard people found it "annoying"... I would find it very frustrating if my job were something few people are interested in. But here in France, you can only have recognized diplomas and be assured you can maybe get a job if you study ""classical"" music... I'm confused. What should I do? 

     "assured you can maybe get a job" seems legit..... on an unrelated note, opera is 97% obsolete. that doesn't mean it's not good, and that doesn't mean you're not allowed to do it, or like it. but 'opera' is mainly a thing from a very different time than ours. i mainly cite technological reasons; microphones and speakers were not invented back then

8.8.17  4:09 am   what is attack, decay, sustain and release?

     attack is how quickly the note starts. so if 'attack' is set all the way short, the note starts immediately when you press the note. if 'attack' is set to a longer setting, the note will gradually fade in when you press the note. Decay is what happens to the note when you keep holding it down. very short decay means the note will drop off to silence immediately, even if you are holding it down. longer decay means it will fade out very very slowly as you hold it down, or maybe even never fade. release is what happens to the note after you let go. short release means the note disappears instantly when you let go. long release means it lingers after you let go, and fades slowly, or even if you set the release to maximum, it will probably stay forever. Sustain is an additional bonus option. instead of "decay" decaying to 0 volume, you can set 'sustain' at a certain level and that will be the volume level that it decays to while you are still holding the note down. then when you let go, the 'release' happens from there. so for example, if you set all 4 sliders (attack, decay, sustain, release) to "medium", and you press your note and hold it, the note will fade in at a medium pace, then drop down at a medium pace to a medium level. then when you let go it will drop to silence at a medium pace. i hope that makes sense

love you!

8.8.17  2:39 am   I just found all my C's and I discovered that the ones on the left (the lower ones) make a "BLEEEH" sound, and the ones in the middle sound like circles, and the high ones make a "tng" sound and make my face scrunch up.  also they ring out more even when I lift up my finger.  I don't like that.  What's my next step?

     go to the middle of the keyboard. take every white note from C to the next C. so that should be 8 notes (c, d, e, f, g, a, b, c). Now, see what songs you can play! just using those notes. hint: start with like popular kids songs

     go to the middle of the keyboard. take every white note from C to the next C. so that should be 8 notes (c, d, e, f, g, a, b, c). Now, see what songs you can play! just using those notes. hint: start with like popular kids songs

8.7.17  11:27 pm   When I try to play chords I always play the first inversion of the chord because I'm used to the shape. How do I learn how the 2nd an 3rd inversions because I get confused if my right thumb isn't on the root of the chord. Do good players somehow just really quickly process in their head what position their fingers need to be or did they practice every inversion on every key?

     you really need to get this. it might seem scary at first but it doesn't take long. look at it this way, take a small range -- like the range right around middle C, (because that's actually the range the probably most chords will want to be) -- and make every chord fit right in there. because this is actually what your inversion skills are going to be used for. playing multiple chords in 1 range without having to jump the range just because you only know a certain inversion. so just pick one small range and make all the chords fit in there. then slide the range up by a 5th or so, and then do it again, find all your chords in that range. you need to be able to do this and i think you can actually learn it very quickly

8.7.17  9:47 pm   bill!!! important news!!! i pressed notes on my piano and i discovered they make noise when i touch them!!!!!!! holy fuck!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! what do i do now???????

     if you look at the keyboard, you'll notice patterns of white and black keys. it's a repeating pattern, as you can see. there's groups of 2 and 3 black keys. Find the white note immediately to the left of the 2 black keys. that note is called C. the note to the left of the 2 black keys is always C. (i think this is the example note i used in my "music school" video) there are many C's on the keyboard. find them all, notice their similarities and differences. let me know what you find, and if you think you are ready for the next step

8.7.17  9:34 pm   how are computers random. it doesn't make any sense. they run programs that always do a thing in the same way every time but sometimes the object is to not do the same thing every time

     i think the most basic way is to some how derive it from the time asked. for example if you put the smallest possible unit of time into mod10, and then spit out the digit (0-9) corresponding to the exact moment you requested something random, then i think that's pretty random. you really never manipulate it, unless you used another computer

Please teach me where harmony teachers at Conservatoire in London have failed!

8.7.17  7:10 pm   bill, about the whole gotta make videos to go with songs.
YES, videos are nice, and your are visualy crazy and memorable, but as you just said, you write and record songs 4x times faster than making a video. so bill, my good man, you have a ton of compositions to actually record for our ears delight, just put the songs on youtube with a spinning record and thats IT. make a full on video for like "singles" if i may out it that way.

i'm sorry about my ranting here, you are already bombarded with questions, requests and all, but i love your songs so much it pains me to see that you think that only videos could help you spread your music, that's why i think that a simple visual on youtube would still get you millions of views/listens, and keep big videos for songs that particularly call you for a complimentary video.

     yes, i realize i could put title videos on youtube. i am considering doing that, but still unsure. the good news is, i receive insane amounts of pressure from people to do that, which helps me think more clearly about it

"flat 2 major 7." or bIIM7 although I prefer to use maj, just so it's extra clear not to be confused with minor. and i personally prefer to use minus sign - for minor. and even more personal is that i prefer to just not even use roman numerals because it's been a long time since rome. but that's just my preference. that being said it really doesn't matter as long as it us understood by whomever is reading it
